newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINNISH PAPER WORKERS SAY DOOR OPEN TO BROAD DEAL.
newsitem.headline: FINNISH PAPER WORKERS SAY DOOR OPEN TO BROAD DEAL.

text.p: The Finnish Paper Workers' Union does not rule out joining a centralised incomes settlement for 1998 if one could solve its specific issues, although that is unlikely, union chairman Jarmo Lahteenmaki said on Thursday.
"We have not closed the door to that option, but I must say that I find it unlikely that a centralised deal could solve our special problems," Lahteenmaki told Reuters by telephone.

The union on Wednesday resumed talks with forest industry emplkoyers to solve five key issues, for instance in job delineation, and Lahteenmaki said it could be seen around the turn of September-October whether a deal was possible.

Lahteenmaki said the union had five demands; limiting employment of non-union paper workers for paper mills maintenance jobs, shorter working hours, better lay-off conditions, applying paper workers' labour terms more widely, and more personnel funds.

The Federation of Finnish Forest Industries' chief negotiator Mauri Moren said on Wednesday that talking could solve the disagreements, but he did not specify the industry's target for the next pay deal.

Experts say the Paper Workers Union -- a leading export sector union with strong influence within Finland's largest union lobby, the 1.1 million member Central Organisation of Finnish Trade Unions (SAK) -- is a crucial party in attempts at a comprehensive national incomes deal with moderate pay hikes.
